comment.author: 18753752@N00
comment._content: William Booth founded the Salvation Army. He died Aug. 20, 1912, so this picture would probably have been taken a few days later. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Booth

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: (William) Bramwell Booth was William Booth's eldest son, and became the 2nd General of the Salvation Army after his father's death.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: captainslack and lifeasdaddy: Thanks for the information. We will add it to the source data and reload the description. According to the Salvation Army International Heritage Center: www1.salvationarmy.org.uk/uki/www_uki_ihc.nsf/vw-sublinks... the funeral took place on August 29, 1912.

comment.author: 25825879@N05
comment._content: William Booth is buried in Abney Park Cemetery, Stoke Newington,London together with his wife and other leaders of the Salvation Army. The headstone on his grave confidently claims he "went to Heaven".

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: William Booth's funeral was held on August 27, 1912.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Wystan, I agree with you that General Booth's funeral was held at Olympia on August 27. It appears that his remains were taken to International Headquarters overnight for his funeral procession the next day, August 28. Although it sheds no light on the dates, here is a pretty good film clip about the events: www.youtube.com/watch?v=fmVqoGzp3-o I tend to think that the event photographed above may have been part of the funeral procession on August 28.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Bob, I hadn't realized that the Procession was a separate event. That film is fascinating, and shows the amazing turnout that day, of mourners and the curious. The New York Times report puts the date of the Procession on August 29. NYT story, August 30, 1912: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E06E3D91630E2...

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Wystan - I don't want to give the impression that I actually knew that the funeral and procession were on consecutive dates without having to search for it. That's not the sort of thing bouncing around in my head. I have seen the date of the funeral/procession vary across the August 27/28/29 including in some online archived newspaper accounts published here in Australia - so I'm not 100% certain. Here's an example published in Australia one month after the event: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article5339166 I would like to check the Times of London report, which would probably be authoritative but it's behind a paywall. As one would expect of such a significant figure there are several published biographies and I can tell from limited previews and snippets at Google Books that some have extensive accounts of these events - but I could not come up with a conclusive, authoritative date because I could not read the full texts. An example of misdating appears in the otherwise excellent National Library of France which carries a photograph showing a similar scene to that above, dated 31-8-12 : gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b6921189t.item.r=william+bo...
